partintro.para: svnlook is a command-line utility for examining different aspects of a Subversion repository. It does not make any changes to the repository—it's just used for peeking. svnlook is typically used by the repository hooks, but a repository administrator might find it useful for diagnostic purposes.
Since svnlook works via direct repository access (and thus can be used only on the machine that holds the repository), it refers to the repository with a path, not a URL.
If no revision or transaction is specified, svnlook defaults to the youngest (most recent) revision of the repository.
Options in svnlook are global, just as they are in svn and svnadmin; however, most options apply to only one subcommand since the functionality of svnlook is (intentionally) limited in scope:

listitem.para: Causes svnlook changed to show detailed copy source information.

Specifies an external program to use to show differences between files. When svnlook diff is invoked without this option, it uses Subversion's internal differencing engine, which provides unified diffs by default. If you want to use an external differencing program, use --diff-cmd. You can then pass options to the specified program using the --extensions (-x) option.
Print differences for copied items against the copy source.
Specifies customizations which Subversion should make when performing difference calculations. Valid extensions include:
Ignore changes in the amount of white space.
Ignore all white space.
Ignore changes in EOL (end-of-line) style.
Show C function names in the diff output.
Show three lines of unified diff context.
The default value is -u.

Note that when Subversion is configured to invoke an external diff command, the value of the --extension (-x) option isn't restricted to the previously mentioned options, but may be any additional arguments which Subversion should pass to that command. If you wish to pass multiple arguments, you must enclose all of them in quotes.
Causes svnlook tree to display full paths instead of hierarchical, indented path components.
Instructs svnlook diff to suppress output of property changes.
Limit output to a maximum number of ARG items.

Prevents svnlook diff from printing differences for deleted files. The default behavior when a file is deleted in a transaction/revision is to print the same differences that you would see if you had left the file but removed all the content.

Prevents svnlook diff from printing differences for added files. The default behavior when you add a file is to print the same differences that you would see if you had added the entire contents of an existing (empty) file.
Operate on a single directory only.
Instructs svnlook diff to show only property changes.
Specifies a particular revision number that you wish to examine.
Operates on a revision property instead of a property specific to a file or directory. This option requires that you also pass a revision with the --revision (-r) option.
Works with svnlook propget and svnlook proplist to display the versioned properties inherited by a path.
Specifies a particular transaction ID that you wish to examine.
Shows the filesystem node revision IDs for each path in the filesystem tree.
Be verbose. When used with svnlook proplist, for example, this causes Subversion to display not just the list of properties, but their values also.
Prints output in XML format.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the author of a revision or transaction in the repository.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: svnlook author is handy, but not very exciting:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook author -r 40 /var/svn/repos sally

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the contents of a file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the contents of a file.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the contents of a file in transaction ax8, located at /trunk/README:

informalexample.screen:
$ svnlook cat -t ax8 /var/svn/repos /trunk/README
Subversion, a version control system. =====================================
$LastChangedDate: 2003-07-17 10:45:25 -0500 (Thu, 17 Jul 2003) $
Contents:
I. A FEW POINTERS II. DOCUMENTATION III. PARTICIPATING IN THE SUBVERSION COMMUNITY …

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the paths that were changed.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the paths that were changed in a particular revision or transaction, as well as svn update-style status letters in the first two columns:

listitem.para: Item added to repository
Item deleted from repository
File contents changed
Properties of item changed; note the leading underscore
File contents and properties changed

refsect1.para: Files and directories can be distinguished, as directory paths are displayed with a trailing / character.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows a list of all the changed files and directories in revision 39 of a test repository. Note that the first changed item is a directory, as evidenced by the trailing /:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook changed -r 39 /var/svn/repos A trunk/vendors/deli/ A trunk/vendors/deli/chips.txt A trunk/vendors/deli/sandwich.txt A trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt U trunk/vendors/baker/bagel.txt _U trunk/vendors/baker/croissant.txt UU trunk/vendors/baker/pretzel.txt D trunk/vendors/baker/baguette.txt

refsect1.para: Here's an example that shows a revision in which a file was renamed:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook changed -r 64 /var/svn/repos A trunk/vendors/baker/toast.txt D trunk/vendors/baker/bread.txt

refsect1.para: Unfortunately, nothing in the preceding output reveals the connection between the deleted and added files. Use the --copy-info option to make this relationship more apparent:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook changed -r 64 --copy-info /var/svn/repos A + trunk/vendors/baker/toast.txt (from trunk/vendors/baker/bread.txt:r63) D trunk/vendors/baker/bread.txt

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the datestamp of a revision or transaction in a repository.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the date of revision 40 of a test repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook date -r 40 /var/svn/repos/ 2003-02-22 17:44:49 -0600 (Sat, 22 Feb 2003)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print differences of changed files and properties.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print GNU-style differences of changed files and properties in a repository.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows a newly added (empty) file, a modified binary file, and a renamed (that is, copied and deleted) file with modifications:

informalexample.screen:
$ svnlook diff -r 40 /var/svn/repos Copied: trunk/relish.txt (from rev 39, trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt) =================================================================== --- trunk/relish.txt (rev 0) +++ trunk/relish.txt 2013-01-29 20:39:17 UTC (rev 40) @@ -0,0 +1 @@ +Pickle relish is mostly made from cucumbers.
Deleted: trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt =================================================================== --- trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt (rev 39) +++ trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt 2013-01-29 20:39:17 UTC (rev 49) @@ -1 +0,0 @@ -Pickles are mostly made from cucumbers.
Modified: trunk/vendors/deli/logo.jpg =================================================================== (Binary files differ)
Added: trunk/vendors/deli/soda.txt =================================================================== $

refsect1.para: By default, svnlook diff will treat copied files very much like any other added file, displaying in their entirety the contents of the new file and merely using a different label to draw the copy/add distinction. However, you can use the --diff-copy-from option to cause svnlook diff to consider a copied file as worthy of mention only if it differs from the file from which it was copied, and to actually describe those differences.

informalexample.screen:
$ svnlook diff -r 40 /var/svn/repos --diff-copy-from Copied: trunk/relish.txt (from rev 39, trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt) =================================================================== --- trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt 2013-01-29 20:39:17 UTC (rev 39) +++ trunk/relish.txt 2013-01-29 20:47:40 UTC (rev 3) @@ -1 +1 @@ -Pickles are mostly made from cucumbers. +Pickle relish is mostly made from cucumbers.
Deleted: trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt =================================================================== --- trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt (rev 39) +++ trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt 2013-01-29 20:39:17 UTC (rev 40) @@ -1 +0,0 @@ -Pickles are mostly made from cucumbers.
Modified: trunk/vendors/deli/logo.jpg =================================================================== (Binary files differ)
Added: trunk/vendors/deli/soda.txt ============================================================================== $

refsect1.para: Use the --no-diff-deleted option to silence output regarding deleted files.

informalexample.screen:
$ svnlook diff -r 40 /var/svn/repos --no-diff-deleted Copied: trunk/relish.txt (from rev 39, trunk/vendors/deli/pickle.txt) =================================================================== --- trunk/relish.txt (rev 0) +++ trunk/relish.txt 2013-01-29 20:39:17 UTC (rev 40) @@ -0,0 +1 @@ +Pickle relish is mostly made from cucumbers.
Modified: trunk/vendors/deli/logo.jpg =================================================================== (Binary files differ)
Added: trunk/vendors/deli/soda.txt ============================================================================== $

refsect1.para: Note that in each of the previous examples, when a file has a nontextual svn:mime-type property, the differences are not explicitly shown.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the directories that were themselves changed.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the directories that were themselves changed (property edits) or whose file children were changed.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the directories that changed in revision 40 in our sample repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook dirs-changed -r 40 /var/svn/repos trunk/vendors/deli/

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the size (in bytes) of a versioned file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the file size (in bytes) of the file located at PATH_IN_REPOS in the HEAD revision of the repository identified by REPOS_PATH as a base-10 integer followed by an end-of-line character. Use the --revision (-r) and --transaction (-t) options to specify a version of the file other than HEAD whose file size you wish to display.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: The following demonstrates how to display the size of the trunk/vendors/deli/soda.txt file as it appeared in revision 40 of our sample repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook filesize -r 40 /var/svn/repos trunk/vendors/deli/soda.txt 23 $

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Displays the help message for svnlook. This command, like its brother, svn help, is also your friend, even though you never call it anymore and forgot to invite it to your last party.

refsect1.title: Options
refsect1.para: None

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print information about the history of a path in the repository (or the root directory if no path is supplied).

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print information about the history of a path in the repository (or the root directory if no path is supplied).

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the history output for the path /branches/bookstore as of revision 13 in our sample repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook history -r 13 /var/svn/repos /branches/bookstore --show-ids REVISION PATH <ID> -------- --------- 13 /branches/bookstore <1.1.r13/390> 12 /branches/bookstore <1.1.r12/413> 11 /branches/bookstore <1.1.r11/0> 9 /trunk <1.0.r9/551> 8 /trunk <1.0.r8/131357096> 7 /trunk <1.0.r7/294> 6 /trunk <1.0.r6/353> 5 /trunk <1.0.r5/349> 4 /trunk <1.0.r4/332> 3 /trunk <1.0.r3/335> 2 /trunk <1.0.r2/295> 1 /trunk <1.0.r1/532>

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the author, datestamp, log message size, and log message.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the author, datestamp, log message size (in bytes), and log message, followed by a newline character.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the info output for revision 40 in our sample repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook info -r 40 /var/svn/repos sally 2003-02-22 17:44:49 -0600 (Sat, 22 Feb 2003) 16 Rearrange lunch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: If a lock exists on a path in the repository, describe it.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print all information available for the lock at PATH_IN_REPOS. If PATH_IN_REPOS is not locked, print nothing.

refsect1.title: Options
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This describes the lock on the file tree.jpg:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook lock /var/svn/repos tree.jpg UUID Token: opaquelocktoken:ab00ddf0-6afb-0310-9cd0-dda813329753 Owner: harry Created: 2005-07-08 17:27:36 -0500 (Fri, 08 Jul 2005) Expires: Comment (1 line): Rework the uppermost branches on the bald cypress in the foreground.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the log message, followed by a newline character.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the log message.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the log output for revision 40 in our sample repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook log /var/svn/repos/ Rearrange lunch.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the raw value of a property on a path in the repository.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: List the value of a property on a path in the repository.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the value of the seasonings property on the file /trunk/sandwich in the HEAD revision:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook pg /var/svn/repos seasonings /trunk/sandwich mustard

refsect1.para: This shows the inherited values of the svn:auto-props property on the directory /trunk in revision 14:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook pg repos svn:auto-props trunk --show-inherited-props -v -r14 Inherited properties on '/trunk', from '/': svn:auto-props *.py = svn:eol-style=native *.c = svn:eol-style=native *.h = svn:eol-style=native

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print the names and values of versioned file and directory properties.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: List the properties of a path in the repository. With --verbose (-v), show the property values too.

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the names of properties set on the file /trunk/README in the HEAD revision:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook proplist /var/svn/repos /trunk/README original-author svn:mime-type

refsect1.para: This is the same command as in the preceding example, but this time showing the property values as well:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook -v proplist /var/svn/repos /trunk/README original-author : harry svn:mime-type : text/plain

refsect1.para: This shows the properties inherited by a directory:

informalexample.screen:
$ svnlook pl /var/svn/repos branches --show-inherited-props -v Inherited properties on '/branches', from '/': svn:auto-props *.py = svn:eol-style=native *.c = svn:eol-style=native *.h = svn:eol-style=native
svn:global-ignores *.diff *.patch
Properties on '/branches':

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the tree, starting at PATH_IN_REPOS (if supplied; at the root of the tree otherwise), optionally showing node revision IDs.

refsect1.title: Example
refsect1.para: This shows the tree output for revision 13 in our sample repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook tree -r 13 /var/svn/repos / trunk/ button.c Makefile integer.c branches/ bookstore/ button.c Makefile integer.c …

refsect1.para: Use the --show-ids option to include node revision IDs (unique internal identifiers for specific nodes in Subversion's versioned filesystem implementation):

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook tree -r 13 /var/svn/repos --show-ids / <0.0.r13/811> trunk/ <1.0.r9/551> button.c <2.0.r9/238> Makefile <3.0.r7/41> integer.c <4.0.r6/98> branches/ <5.0.r13/593> bookstore/ <1.1.r13/390> button.c <2.1.r12/85> Makefile <3.0.r7/41> integer.c <4.1.r13/109> …

refsect1.para: For output which lends itself more readily to being parsed by scripts, use the --full-paths option, which causes svnlook to print the full repository path of each tree item and to not use indentation to indicate hierarchy:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook tree -r 13 /var/svn/repos --show-ids --full-paths / <0.0.r13/811> trunk/ <1.0.r9/551> trunk/button.c <2.0.r9/238> trunk/Makefile <3.0.r7/41> trunk/integer.c <4.0.r6/98> branches/ <5.0.r13/593> branches/bookstore/ <1.1.r13/390> branches/bookstore/button.c <2.1.r12/85> branches/bookstore/Makefile <3.0.r7/41> branches/bookstore/integer.c <4.1.r13/109> …

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the UUID for the repository. The UUID is the repository's universal unique identifier. The Subversion client uses this identifier to differentiate between one repository and another.

refsect1.title: Options
refsect1.para: None

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook uuid /var/svn/repos e7fe1b91-8cd5-0310-98dd-2f12e793c5e8

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Print the youngest revision number of a repository.

refsect1.title: Options
refsect1.para: None

refsect1.title: Examples
refsect1.para: This shows the youngest revision of our sample repository:

informalexample.screen: $ svnlook youngest /var/svn/repos/ 42
